newsitem.title: UK: UK 5-yr dual gilt sale bodes well for second leg.
newsitem.headline: UK 5-yr dual gilt sale bodes well for second leg.

text.p: Demand at the auction of 2.0 billion stg of five-year gilts on Tuesday surpassed even the most optimistic expectations and sets the stage for a successful sale of longer-dated paper on Thursday, analysts said.

"I was more bullish than most and it was even a little stronger than I had expected," said Steve Scott, gilts analyst at Kleinwort Benson. "It sets the market up well for the longer auction on Thursday."
Tuesday's auction of 2.0 billion stg of 7.0 percent gilts due 2001 was covered 3.57 times.
The Bank of England will auction 1.5 billion stg of 8.0 percent stock due 2015 on Thursday in the second leg of its dual auction.
Analysts said it was unlikely the Bank will tap the longer end of the curve for some time after this week, lending further support to the auction.
The yield tale at Tuesday's auction was zero basis points and there was no price tail.
Analysts said the sale was helped by the fact the short end of the gilt curve was relatively cheap at present.

"The auction was very encouraging and should help the second leg go better," said Philip Shaw, group economist at Union Plc. "But having said that, we have had a near 25 basis point increase in yields at the short end so it was relatively cheap."

Kleinwort Benson's Scott said the modest size of the auction, the fact it was short-dated paper and the cheaper levels all helped the sale. "The market got ahead of it and so provided an opportunity to buy at good yield levels," he said.
Dealers said the healthy demand for the paper would give the gilt market a psychological boost ahead of September retail sales data due on Wednesday.
Economists expect British retail sales eased 0.1 percent in September from August but are confident the trend in consumer spending is still firmly upwards.
Tuesday's auction success mirrors that of the Bank's ground-breaking dual auction in July. Then, 2.0 billion stg of 8.0 percent gitls due 2000 were covered 4.81 times, also with no yield tale.
The second part of the sale, 1.5 billion stg of the same longer dated stock that is on offer on Thursday, was also well received, attracting cover of 1.88 times.

UK gilts rose slightly on the auction result with the December gilt future rising to 109-24 from 109-22 before. The positive sentiment was further buoyed by the latest CBI survey which showed inflationary pressures remained subdued.
The December gilt stood at 109-26 during lunchtime trade, up 14/32 on the day.
